posts.name:
Kunal Pandya
Kunal Pandya
posts.content:
Feel like your work in enablement isn‚Äôt getting the recognition it deserves? I get it.

Because I‚Äôve been there.

At the beginning of my enablement career, I thought I was doing everything right.

I followed the advice that people kept shouting about:

‚ÄúTrack activity metrics like calls and emails.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe product sells itself - just teach reps how to sell better.‚Äù
‚ÄúFocus on onboarding - it‚Äôs what the business cares about.‚Äù

Here‚Äôs the truth: that advice didn't work.

Why? Because it was completely out of touch with the challenges I actually faced in my job everyday:

 Conflicting demands from sales, leadership, and ops.
 Pressure to justify value in challenging economic climates.
 More savvy buyers and increased competition.
 Minimal guidance on how to tie enablement efforts to business outcomes.

I wasted a lot of time following advice that wasn‚Äôt helping me move the needle.

And here's what I had to learn the hard way, though. a lot of trial and error: Leadership doesn‚Äôt care how many training sessions you run...

They care about one thing: revenue.

If you‚Äôre not showing how your work ties back to revenue, your efforts will largely go unnoticed.

I wish someone had told me that at the beginning of my enablement career.

It's also why so many enablers are stuck...

 Drowning in overhyped information that‚Äôs no longer relevant.
 Burning out doing tactical tasks that don't get them a promotion.
 Trying to piece together advice that doesn't actually solve the bigger challenges enablement faces in 2025.

The problem isn‚Äôt you - it‚Äôs the noise.

What you need isn‚Äôt more generic advice that isn't relevant to the struggles you deal with on a daily basis.

What you DO need is clarity, strategy and guidance that aligns with the world enablement is living and breathing in today.

Enablement will only STOP being branded as the "training and support function" and START being recognised as a revenue-driving function, when we choose to step up and learn how to demonstrate revenue impact. If there is one skill you master in 2025, let it be THAT!

P.S That‚Äôs exactly why I created the Strategic Enablement Blueprint. It‚Äôs the roadmap I wish I had when I started. A framework to cut through the noise and show you how to make an impact, get a promotion and remain relevant in today's competitive market. Join the waitlist here:
posts.commentAdded: Great insights! Mastering the art of demonstrating revenue impact is crucial for enablement professionals. Looking forward to the Strategic Enablement Blueprint!

posts.name:
Jason Portnoy
Jason Portnoy
posts.content:
ROI is a SHARED outcome!

It‚Äôs not just about the agency and the traffic...

It‚Äôs about alignment between the efforts of BOTH the client and the agency.

The agency's role is to ensure the traffic sent are highly qualified while managing costs effectively.

The client‚Äôs responsibility is to create a user experience that converts those visitors into leads or sales.

Both roles are essential.... And when either side isn‚Äôt optimized, the ROI suffers.

The relationship between agency and client is a PARTNERSHIP, not an abdication of the business's responsibilities.
posts.commentAdded: Absolutely! A true partnership fosters success‚Äîboth agency and client play vital roles in driving ROI. Collaboration is key! üí™üöÄ

posts.name:
Hunter Deskin
Hunter Deskin
posts.content:
I didn‚Äôt even want this. And Cialdini‚Äôs Law of Reciprocity struck again. The lesson?


I was at sprouts grocery yesterday with my girlfriend getting some dinner and groceries.

There‚Äôs a salad that we really like in the side section‚Ä¶

We already know we like it.

Yet this new one caught our eye.

The guy saw me looking at it.

I told him I‚Äôm good I think we will just keep going.

He said you sure? I‚Äôll give you a sample?

Now, they‚Äôve done this before.

Offered me samples of stuff I was considering buying.

But this guy heaped an entire serving size portion of it into a container and handed it to me.

I‚Äôm talking 10x what they normally give.

Tbh I didn‚Äôt even like it.

Yet I bought a pound of it anyway.

Why?

Reciprocity.

The guy was so kind as to give me an entire serving as a sample I couldn‚Äôt help but buy some afterwards.

It felt indebted to him DESPITE knowing this principle and it viscerally playing out before me.

The lesson?

Give give give.

Give more than you think.

Make your lead magnets and content so full of information and value your prospects can‚Äôt HELP but feel indebted to you and like the HAVE to buy your stuff.

comments.commentText: Dang twelve bucks a pound for leaves is wild haha

posts.commentAdded: Great story! It‚Äôs fascinating how the Law of Reciprocity influences our decisions. Truly a reminder to give value and build genuine connections!

posts.content:
‚ÄúBaat pissa ki koni, baat hisaab ki hai!‚Äù
Translation: It‚Äôs never about the money; it‚Äôs the calculations that matter most. You can take a Marwari out of the ‚Äúdhandha,‚Äù but never the ‚Äúdhandha mindset‚Äù out of them.

Despite working in the corporate world for 8+ years, my budgeting and investing principles are rooted in lessons from my businessman father:
a) Know how much is coming in and from where.
b) ALWAYS know how much is being spent and on what.
c) Hunt for the best deals to ensure you get your money‚Äôs worth.

As someone who loves good deals as much as keeping a hisaab, I rely on multiple credit cards and managing them can get chaotic.

For years, I‚Äôve been juggling gazillion Excel sheets (because old habits die hard). But now, I useto manage my credit cards effortlessly. And they‚Äôve just made it even better with CheQ Wisor‚ÄîIndia‚Äôs first AI-driven credit card expert! It gives me:

posts.name:
Michael Ocean
Michael Ocean
posts.content:
If your sales team is crushing it, don't mess with it.


Had a great chat with(Director of GTC Programs at Polaris, NY Chapter President at Revenue Enablement Society) about when you actually need a sales methodology - and when you don't.


Her take? While methodologies can help struggling teams, there's no reason to change what's already working well.


When to consider a methodology:

- Your team isn't hitting their numbers and needs a clear framework
- You want customers to have the same experience, no matter which seller they work with
- You need better ways to track and measure sales effectiveness


In the full episode, we covered:

- Getting real buy-in from CEO to sales reps
- Rolling out methodologies without breaking what works
- Why customer experience drives methodology choice
- The right balance between structure and sales flexibility


Full conversation in the comments

comments.commentText:
"Standardizing how we sell isn't just about internal processes. It's about making sure every customer gets the same amazing experience, regardless of which seller they're working with." Smart way to think about sales process.

Full episode here:
Can't wait to watch this one!

posts.commentAdded: Great insights! Its crucial to strike that balance between structure and flexibility. Excited to hear more from your conversation!

posts.name:
Ronen Olshansky
Ronen Olshansky
posts.content:
You‚Äôll network better by being yourself.

People can spot fake from a mile away.

In this video, you‚Äôll see a group of dolphins swimming their usual patterns, mostly ignoring the crowd.

Then this little girl steps up to the glass.

No agenda. No performance. Just pure childlike wonder and joy.

One dolphin noticed. Broke away from the group. Came right to her window.

What followed was heartwarming ‚Äî a pure connection between two beings just happy to share a moment.

This made me think about networking and connection:

‚Ä¢ How often do we overcomplicate things?
‚Ä¢ How many walls do we build with our "professional personas"?
‚Ä¢ What if we led with authenticity?

The best way to connect isn't through polished facades.

You‚Äôll make more progress being real enough that others feel safe being real too.

When was the last time you dropped the corporate mask and let your genuine self shine through?

comments.commentText:
Ronen Olshansky authenticity breaks down walls faster than any polished act ever could; real connections come from being genuinely you! And I'm working on something... Imagine a business event that never ends... and you can join anytime, anywhere. Think of it as your 24/7 social networking!
It is something fresh, new and unique - focused on professionals looking for authentic and meaningful connections - ONLY!

posts.commentAdded: Absolutely love this perspective! Authenticity truly paves the way for deeper connections. Lets embrace our true selves in networking! üåä‚ú®

posts.name:
Slava Pisanka
Slava Pisanka
posts.content:
I fell into low-bid RFP trap and paid a high price.

Back in 2005 I did an ERP system selection and picked the best contender:
¬∑      The solution was the right fit for the client
¬∑      The vendor seemed to have the right expertise
¬∑      Good reputation
¬∑      Best price

After the selection I led the project as a project manager and the implementation consultant.

The first few months of the project went OK. But then the SI started delaying on deliverables.

A little later they completely changed the solution, the team, and started asking for more money.

Change request. Cha Ching!

By that time, we already paid per contract. So, the choice was to break up and sue them or pay.

The vendor was asking to pay for additional features, expended timeline and many more.

The client decided to extend the party.

As the result the project took 2 years instead of 1 year promised, and we went 100% over budget.

Now let‚Äôs look at what happened here.

This system integrator used a playbook that many vendors love:
1.     Bid low to win the deal. Pretend to be cost competitive.
2.     Scope creep everything
3.     Recover revenue that was lost at the beginning

Result for the client?
¬∑      Budget overrun
¬∑      Timeline delay
¬∑      Frustrated stakeholders

How can you avoid this trap?
1.     Focus less on a cost but more on the right vendor
2.     Have an experienced ERP consultant in your team who can see the low bidding
3.     Hire an independent ERP advisor who can help you spot red flags and make the right decisions

Hey, but I have a rock-solid RFP process!

Right. You will find out later.
posts.commentAdded: Great insights! Prioritizing the right vendor over the lowest bid can save time and money in the long run. Lessons learned!
